description: Borrowed from Latin inculcātus, perfect passive participle of inculcō (“impress upon, force upon”), from in + calcō (“tread upon, trample”), from calx (“heel”).

verbs.description: inculcate (third-person singular simple present inculcates, present participle inculcating, simple past and past participle inculcated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To induce understanding or a particular sentiment in a person or persons.
examples: all preachers , especially such as be of good temper , and have wisdom with conscience , ought to inculcate and beat upon a peace , silence , and surseance
